title-group.article-title: Framework for life cycle sustainability assessment of municipal solid waste management systems with an application to a case study in Thailand

article-meta.aff: 1The Joint Graduate School of Energy and Environment, King Mongkut’s University of Technology Thonburi, Bangkok, Thailand
2Center for Energy Technology and Environment, Ministry of Education, Thailand

author-notes.corresp: Shabbir H Gheewala, The Joint Graduate School of Energy and Environment, King Mongkut’s University of Technology Thonburi, 126 Pracha-Uthit Road, Bangmod, Tungkru, Bangkok 10140, Thailand Email address: shabbir_g@jgsee.kmutt.ac.th

abstract.p: At present, there are many environmental, economic and social problems associated with poor municipal solid waste (MSW) management in Thailand. The development of sustainable solid waste management systems is a crucial aspect and should be based on an integrated approach. Therefore, an integrated system was designed for Nonthaburi Municipality incorporating recycling, anaerobic digestion, incineration and landfill technologies. In order to assess sustainability, a clear methodology was developed via life cycle thinking and a set of endpoint composite indicators has been proposed considering the most critical ultimate damages/effects of MSW management on the environment, the economy and society. The results showed that the appropriate integration of technologies offers important prospects with regards to socio-economic and environmental aspects, contributing, therefore, to improved sustainability for the overall MSW management system. The methodology and the proposed indicators would be useful in strategic planning, including decision- and policy-making with respect to the development of appropriate sustainable MSW management systems.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Similar to other Asian countries, open dumping and non-engineered landfilling are the two predominant waste disposal methods in Thailand. In 2009, the volume of garbage in Thailand rose to approximately 41,410 tonnes per day. Approximately 22% is separated and sent to recycling centers and the remaining fraction is open dumped or landfilled (PCD, 2009). Thus, the presently practised open dumping and landfilling methods have negative influences in the form of severe environmental degradation, economic losses and social burdens. In order to overcome the problem, the current state-of-the-art of solid waste disposal is based on the concept of integrated management, which includes the reclamation of useful material/energy (Kathiravale and Yunus, 2008).

In this study, Nonthaburi Municipality, which is situated 20 km northwest of Bangkok, was selected as the study location. This municipality covers an area of 39 km2, hosting a population of 0.27 million. At present, the average amount of municipal solid waste (MSW) generation in the municipality is 370 tonnes per day. Nonthaburi Municipality is making an effort to maximize recycling and minimize waste generation. As a result, 24% waste recycling was achieved in 2010 (personal communication). The remaining 76% of generated waste is disposed of in a sanitary landfill without a gas recovery system. Therefore, the existing landfill is a cause of serious environmental degradation, economic losses and social burdens. In order to minimize such burdens, a potential integrated system was considered for Nonthaburi Municipality. In order to assess sustainability, an attempt was made to broaden the application of a traditional environmental life cycle assessment (LCA) to a more comprehensive three-dimensional sustainability assessment.

sec.title: Development of a LCA framework for sustainability assessment
sec.p: There is an increasing interest in the application of the LCA concept to sustainable development, (Guinée et al., 2011). Thus, a life cycle framework is used as the systematic basis for developing indicators and sustainability assessment (Finnveden et al., 2009; Ortiz et al., 2009). It is necessary to consider all the phases of the life cycle in a methodical approach. In addition to the direct activities, energy and materials recovery potential from different technologies should be accounted for as there is a possibility for the replacement of the virgin production processes (Liamsanguan and Gheewala, 2008). Considering all those aspects, inventory analysis can be done for the entire life cycle of MSW management systems by compiling all the inputs and outputs within the system boundaries. Based on the inventory results different types of indicators can be distinguished. The expanded LCA methodology for life cycle sustainability assessment of MSW system is described in the section below.

sec.title: ‘Broadening’ and ‘deepening’ of the scope of LCA

list-item.p: Broadening and deepening the scope of ‘traditional environmental LCA assessment’ were done in order to perform the full scale life cycle sustainability assessment of waste management systems. ‘Broadening’ the LCA scope was done by incorporating the three pillars of sustainability into a common LCA framework (Jeswani et al., 2010). ‘Deepening’ the LCA scope was done by adding more mechanisms and/or more sophistication to measure the ultimate damages/effects instead of the traditionally practiced midpoint impact assessment (Figure 1).

caption.p: Conceptual framework for life cycle sustainability assessment of MSW management systems [background information sources for endpoint composite environmental indicators: Goedkoop et al. (2009); Ortiz et al. (2009)].

sec.title: Defining a common LCA framework for life cycle sustainability assessment

list-item.p: LCA framework includes all the phases of life cycle from ‘Cradle to Grave’ of MSW management, including auxiliary material production (energy and raw materials), MSW collection and transportation, treatment and final disposal. In addition, the LCA framework has highlighted the major life cycle inputs that arrive at the system and the major life cycle outputs leaving from the system with respect to the environmental, economic and social aspects (Figure 1).

sec.p: As one can clearly notice in Figure 1, the vast amount of information obtained via life cycle inventory (inputs/outputs) may not meet the needs of decision- and policy-makers in assessing the sustainability. More processed information is needed to facilitate decision-making. Indicators are seen as one solution to bridge this gap. In order to assess the sustainability of the MSW management system, a set of endpoint composite indicators were identified considering the ultimate effects of life cycle inputs/outputs. This type of indicator measures the aggregated effect of various aspects of a given phenomenon, based on a sometimes complex concept, into a single number with a common unit (see Figure 1). Damage-oriented methods (endpoint impacts) can be followed in order to develop endpoint composite indicators to assess the magnitude of the ultimate damages/effects of MSW management on the environment/society and which will be useful in strategic planning, including decision- and policy-making (Ortiz et al., 2009).

sec.title: Assessment of environmental sustainability
sec.p: Endpoint approach classifies flows into various environmental themes and three major composite indicators can be developed for modelling the damage to each theme – human health, natural environment and abiotic resources (see Figure 1). However, even though the damage to human health is caused by environmental emissions, this indicator can be considered as a social indicator too, as safeguarding human health would be of interest to society as a whole (Finnveden et al., 2009). Hence, only ‘damage to ecosystem’ and ‘damage to abiotic resources’ are selected as the major composite indicators for environmental sustainability assessment (see Figure 1).

sec.title: Composite indicator—damage to ecosystem
sec.p: MSW management activities are responsible for causing significant damages to ecosystems at the local level owing to the large amount of acidifying and eutrophying substances emitted to the environment and the considerable area of bioproductive land that is occupied/converted. This damage can be measured based on the concept of potentially disappeared fraction (PDF) of species. Furthermore, to perform a meaningful comparison on the damage to ecosystems caused in different nations, local damage to ecosystems can be converted to global scale damage by multiplying the appropriate equivalence factor and yield factor of the land use types (Scotti et al., 2009; Wackernagel et al., 2005). Yield factors are needed for normalizing the land types available to world average equivalents using locally derived yield factors. These are multipliers that express the extent to which local bioproductivity is more or less than that of the world average for that land type (Scotti et al., 2009). The equivalence factors are needed to represent the average potential productivity of a given bioproductive area relative to the world average potential productivity of all bioproductive areas (Huijbregts et al., 2008; Wackernagel et al., 2005).

sec.title: Composite indicator—damage to abiotic resources
sec.p: MSW management activities consume a significant amount of fossil resources in the form of diesel fuel, electricity and thermal energy consumed in various activities such as transportation, pre-processing and treatment of waste. However, to measure the fossil fuel and mineral resources consumption effects on sustainability in a tangible way, endpoint damage assessment would be appropriate. To this end, in this research, a formula was developed to account for the depletion of abiotic resources, expressed in monetary terms, based on the ReCiPe model concept. It would be an appropriate tool as it has been developed based on the concept of marginal increase in costs to society owing to the continuous extraction of resources and its scarcity. For instance, for the next 1000 giga barrel of crude oil extraction, the price will need to increase by US$30 per barrel (Goedkoop et al., 2009).

The marginal cost increase (MCI) is the factor that represents the increase of the cost of a reference commodity r ($/kg) owing to an extraction. The unit of the marginal cost increase is dollars per kilogram per kilogram ($/kg2) (Goedkoop et al., 2008).

The total additional cost to society owing to an extraction of a significant amount of reference material (e.g. crude oil) can thus be calculated by multiplying the marginal cost increase per kg by the annual consumed amount times future value of a dollar for extraction compared to the base year.
The damage is defined as the additional costs society has to pay as a result of an extraction.

Where, the damage Dr is expressed in $/kg, Pr is the global production amount of the reference resource in the base year (kg), d is the inflation rate and t is the time interval between the current year and the base year.

In order to calculate endpoint impact, midpoint characterization factors (CF mid.i) for ith resources are needed relative to the reference resource. In fact, in the ReCiPe model, the midpoint characterization factors for metals are derived as Fe-equivalents. For fossil fuels, the midpoint characterization factors are derived relative to the energy content of reference resources which would be ‘Oil, crude, feedstock, 42 MJ per kg, in ground’ (Goedkoop et al., 2008).

By using this concept, potential damage caused to abiotic resources can be calculated in terms of money for all the fossil fuel and mineral consumption of a particular MSW management system. Thus, this composite indicator will be beneficial for sustainability assessment and decision making process.

sec.title: Assessment of economic sustainability
sec.p: Economics is a very important decisive factor for municipal waste management (Ngoc and Schnitzer, 2009; Reich, 2005). Sustainability of any MSW management method depends on the total cost of the facility (Lutz et al., 2006) and the willingness of people to pay for a waste management service. Therefore, a detailed financial analysis via life cycle costing (LCC) has been identified as an appropriate economic method in performing a financial feasibility analysis of a particular solid waste management system within the common LCA framework (Lutz et al., 2006; Ngoc and Schnitzer, 2009).

sec.title: Composite indicator—life cycle cost
sec.p: LCC for MSW management system involves evaluation of all the costs related to design and construction of the facility, collection and transportation, processing, operation, maintenance and support, and final material disposal. Therefore, all the cost categories related to waste management, such as total capital expenditure, operation and maintenance costs, and environmental cost (monetary value of the environmental emissions), must be incorporated in the LCC analysis (see Table 1).

sec.p: Present value calculations have to be performed for capital cost, operation, and maintenance costs and revenues to allow the summation of initial and future costs and revenues (Lutz et al., 2006; Utne, 2009).

Operation and maintenance costs would represent a major share of the LCC for a local authority mainly because of high collection and transportation fees. In order to calculate life cycle operation and maintenance costs, labour cost, utilities, operating supplies, accident risk expenditure, insurance and taxes, etc. should be accounted for.

Even though local authorities are not yet concerned about the environmental cost, it should be taken into account for LCC cost estimation as the community may have to bear the costs in the form of health costs owing to environmental pollution. There is no developed model to calculate the externalities considering country-specific situations. Therefore, willingness to pay is estimated as the cost of mitigating the pollutants via improved technologies for avoiding health damages and preserving lives. Considering all those cost factors, a common formula can be developed to calculate LCC as shown in Table 1.

In order to make a final decision on the economic feasibility of a proposed MSW management method, life cycle revenues from the sale of different by-products should also be included to estimate net LCC (see Table 1). Such LCC analysis for a particular MSW management system would provide useful information in terms of long term cost-effectiveness.

sec.title: Assessment of social sustainability
sec.p: In relation to sustainable development and policy making, there has been an increasing interest in the inclusion of social aspects as part of the LCA framework (Finnveden et al., 2009). Social life cycle assessment (Hunkeler, 2006) is a tool that enables assessment of the overall social benefits/effects that can be expected from a particular system.

There is a wide range of social impacts, both positive and negative, associated with MSW management. For instance, poor MSW management practices may lead to a serious threat to human health, including shortened length of life, as a result of environmental pollution and other negative impacts. Also, at times, there is a lack of benefits to the community resulting in public opposition, as well as a lack of stakeholder participation, coordination and commitment to waste management (Giusti, 2009). In contrast, properly designed waste management systems improve the overall social environment and aesthetic conditions. The major social impact of initiating such a system is the possibility of uplifting community well-being. Improving the efficiencies of waste management systems and reducing the environmental emissions would directly help mitigate public health hazards, consequently reducing expenditure by health services. In addition, an appropriate waste management system may provide a significant number of direct and indirect employment opportunities, as well as generating additional income to households from selling recyclables, home composting, etc. Thus, damage to human health and income-based community well-being are suitable indicators to quantify the critical social impacts from waste management.

sec.title: Composite indicator—damage to human health
sec.p: Health issues are associated with the handling, transportation, treatment and disposal of MSW, both directly and indirectly (Giusti, 2009). Damage to human health can be used as the endpoint composite indicator to quantify the overall health damages and it can be measured as disability adjusted life years (DALYs) (PRé Consultants, 2001). This aggregates the years of life lost (YOLL) and years lived disabled (YLD) owing to the impacts caused by emissions. This indicator measures health damage caused by environmental impact categories, such as global warming, photo-oxidant formation and human toxicity (PRé Consultants, 2001; Goedkoop et al. 2009;). The Swedish environmental priority strategies (EPS) model expresses clear correlations between environmental emissions and damage to human health (Steen, 2000). In order to assess the health impacts of emissions from MSW management, relevant characterization factors for mortality (measured as YOLL), severe morbidity and morbidity (measured as YLD) were retrieved from the EPS model.
The generic formula for calculating overall damage to human health considering all possible health impacts is shown in Table 2.

sec.p: Composite indicator—community well-being (income-based measures)

The concept of community well-being is one of the frameworks for social sustainability assessment. Poverty alleviation and economic development are the major aspects towards improving the well-being of the community. Appropriate MSW management systems can enhance the living standards owing to local economic growth by facilitating employment, as well as other income-generation opportunities. In fact, there is a potential to earn a significant amount of money by selling point source separated recyclables. In addition, providing employment opportunities for skilled workers may facilitate the enhancement of the living standard of the individual, as well as her/his family members as it helps to improve family income and, subsequently, aids in poverty reduction.

Facilitating more job opportunities in terms of quality (trained personnel) and quantity would be a good approach to obtain community appreciation. Prior estimation of potential skilled employment opportunities for intended MSW management at the design phase will be a good indicator to show the future social benefits and for convincing the community. Potential generation of employment opportunities at each hierarchal position can be calculated by using social life cycle assessment concept (Hunkeler, 2006). Then, the potential income-based community well-being (number of individuals who may have a ‘good life’) from a particular MSW management system can be calculated by using the formula presented in Table 2.

sec.title: Sustainability assessment and decision-making on different waste-management options
sec.p: The proposed end point indicators would be useful in quantifying environmental, economic and social effects in order to compare the magnitude of sustainability aspects of different MSW management options and to select the most promising approach. At this stage, multi-criteria decision analysis can be used in order to compare the sustainability levels of different waste management options for selection of a preferred option. However, preferences on weighting the importance of sustainability categories may differ from decision-maker to decision-maker; therefore, the outcome depends on who is making the decision and what their goals and preferences are (Dorini et al., 2011).

The other option is the development of a scientifically sound baseline for the decision-making process to compare the magnitude of impacts of a waste management system relative to the baseline. For instance, the ‘zero waste concept’ can be used to develop a baseline to assess the sustainability at the decision-making stage. In the LCA perspective, production of valuable by-products from waste can be credited for avoiding virgin production process chains. The credited processes may over-compensate the negative impacts caused from the waste-management method itself. Owing to this effect, the magnitude of net impacts may reach zero or less than zero values and, therefore, the basic outcome would be similar to the zero waste system. In order to reach sustainability level, each indicator should fulfill Eq. (13).
where i is the MSW treatment method, GI is the gross impact, CI is the credited impact and NI is the net impact

Furthermore, when each sustainability aspect is treated independently (with different units) it is difficult to provide adequate suggestions for policy making. Hence, all three aspects of sustainability should be converted into a common unit (e.g. monetary term) facilitating aggregation to a single index. For this, however, weighting and further aggregation of the proposed composite indicators would imply a ‘subjective’ evaluation (Heijung et al., 2010). A panel of experts with a wide spectrum of knowledge, experience and concerns is needed for the valuation of the end results. However, there are some limitations of this approach, including the introduction of additional uncertainty and subjectivity in the calculations. Some information would, invariably, be lost, as is the case whenever data is aggregated. Taking into account all these considerations, further research is required for developing appropriate methods for weighting and aggregation.

Potential uncertainty related to life cycle sustainability assessment is one of the important aspects to consider prior to decision-making with respect to strategic planning, policy making, etc. Life cycle sustainability assessment comprises a number of phases, each of which would have their associated uncertainties. At the stage of endpoint impact assessment, the uncertainties mainly occur in the process of aggregation of various midpoint impacts into a single category indicator by using characterizations factors, which have been developed based on a significant number of additional, unsubstantiated assumptions (Pré Consultants, 2001).

sec.title: Sustainability assessment of intended integrated MSW management system in Nonthaburi—a case study
sec.p: According to the composition of mixed waste in Nonthaburi, there is the possibility of incorporating mechanical biological treatment and thermal treatment methods. Thus, the intended integrated system was designed by incorporating the most appropriate technologies, such as recycling, anaerobic digestion (AD), incineration and a landfill for residual waste disposal. In order to evaluate the three-dimensional sustainability of the intended integrated MSW management system, a common LCA framework was developed as shown in Figure 2. It includes the major phases of the life cycle, such as collection and transportation of MSW, segregation of biodegradable and combustibles fractions at the sorting facility, and treatment using different technologies. It should be noted that recycling is a different process chain as recyclables are separated at the household level in Nonthaburi. Recycling process chain includes collection and transportation of point source separated waste, pre-processing at the sorting facility and recycling of different fractions of recyclables at the various recycling plants. System expansion was done to account for the recovery of materials and energy from treatment methods. Thus, credits were provided for materials and energy recovered to account for avoiding virgin materials production processes. The functional unit for analysis is ‘management of one tonne of generated MSW in Nonthaburi within the integrated system’.

caption.p: LCA framework of the intended integrated MSW management system in Nonthaburi Municipality.

sec.title: Inventory analysis of the intended integrated MSW management in Nonthaburi
sec.p: Information related to material and energy consumption, cost and revenues, as well as employment opportunities of recycling processes were collected from various sorting plants and recycling facilities in Thailand. Appropriate databases such as Ecoinvent and BUWAL 250 (Hischier and St. Gallen, 2007; Pré Consultants, 2007) were also used to quantify life cycle emissions and resource consumption of recycling. In the inventory analysis, whenever online LCA databases were used (e.g. eco-invent) to find the energy requirement for a unit process of recycling or virgin production of materials those data were adjusted to the Thai context based on the potential energy sources available to provide an equivalent amount of thermal and/or electric energy. Also, emissions from the combustion of local fuel sources were taken into account in the inventory analysis. All the data required on AD, incineration and landfilling was collected from pilot plants which are situated in Rayong Municipality, Phuket Municipality and Nonthaburi Municipality. Additional supporting information in relation to waste transportation, sorting, etc. was obtained from various literature sources (Nithikul et al., 2010; PCD, 2009).

sec.title: Potential of recuperation of materials and energy from the intended integrated system
sec.p: A mass balance analysis was performed to quantify the amount of waste that can be sent to different technologies within the integrated system. It was assumed that, similar to the present situation, 24% of point source separated waste is sent to recycling facilities. In Nonthaburi, the recyclable mix consists of five major categories: paper (23%), plastic (3%), glass (7%), aluminium (27%) and steel (40%)(personal communication). Based on the recyclability of those materials, from one tonne of paper, plastic, glass, aluminium and metal, 850 kg, 900 kg, 950 kg, 760 kg and 900 kg of recycled products can be recovered respectively (Hischier and St. Gallen, 2007; Pré Consultants, 2007).

According to the characteristics of the mixed waste, 36% of MSW can be separated at the sorting facility as the organic fraction to be treated by using AD technology. To estimate the electricity production potential from AD process, plant-specific information (e.g. biogas yield, onsite electricity consumption, etc.) was obtained from the Rayong AD facility in Thailand. In addition, it was considered that the methane content in the produced biogas is 60% and the energy efficiency of the IC engine is 35% (Fruergaard and Astrup, 2009; UNFCCC, 2010). According to the analysis, the estimated net electricity production potential per tonne of organic waste is 192 kWh (Table 3). In addition, the AD process has the potential tp produce a significant amount of compost by using the wet digestate; the estimated compost production potential from sludge is 0.125 tonne/tonne of organic waste. It should be noted that these estimations may vary from location to location based on the waste characteristics and plant efficiencies.

sec.p: About 29% of separated MSW at the sorting facility belong to combustibles which can be treated via incineration. According to the composition of combustibles, electricity production potential amounts to 188 kWh/tonne of combustibles, of which 60 kWh of electricity is utilized for plant operation activities. The remaining 11% of MSW is accounted for as the inert materials. This fraction should be sent to the landfill.

sec.title: Sustainability assessment of the intended integrated system via endpoint composite indicators
Quantification of ‘damage to the ecosystem’
sec.p: Damage to the ecosystem owing to various reasons, such as acidifying and eutrophying substances emission, and direct and indirect land occupation, was estimated and such damages were aggregated to quantify the gross ecosystem damage from the selected technologies. In contrast, the recovery of energy and materials from improved technologies contributes to reduce damage to the ecosystem as a result of the credited processes. Considering all these aspects, the net damage to the ecosystem from different treatment methods was quantified per tonne of waste. The assessment results (Table 4) show the benefits of recycling, AD and incineration technologies as such technologies enhance the ecosystem protection as a result of material and energy recovery. The damage to the ecosystem from the integrated system is also quantified by assimilation of the effects from each technology based on the fraction of waste treated using different technologies.

sec.title: Quantification of damage to abiotic resources
sec.p: The effect of improved technologies and the integrated system on abiotic resources damage was assessed. Among all the appropriate technologies considered, recycling has the highest potential for contributing to the protection of abiotic resources. The estimated net savings would amount to $310 per tonne of mixed recyclables as a result of avoided extraction of minerals (10% of savings) and fossil fuel (90% of savings) which would have otherwise been required for the virgin production process chains.

The analysis results of both AD and incinerations have shown the possibility of contributing to the protection of abiotic resources as a result of the energy recovered from waste in the form of electricity and avoided resources depletion from conventional electricity production (Table 5). In contrast, the designed landfill for residual waste disposal is a net energy consumer and causes damage to abiotic resources.

sec.p: As a result of the combined technologies and recovery of maximum resources and energy from the proposed integrated MSW management system, there is the possibility of saving $81.4 per tonne of MSW to society as a result of avoiding a marginal cost increase for fossil fuel and mineral extraction. Of note is that the recycling of 24% of the waste would substantially influence the final result obtained for the integrated MSW management system proposed.

sec.title: Economic sustainability assessment via LCC
sec.p: According to the financial analysis, it was revealed that the recycling of any type of recyclable is financially feasible. The estimated net LCC of recycling amounted to -11,300 baht/tonne of mix recyclable in Nonthaburi (30.8 baht = 1 US$). The negative values obtained express the potential of ‘net earnings’ from recycling (Figure 3). It should be noted that the amount of revenue generation is highly dependent on the buying price of recyclable waste and the selling price of recovered materials. Price fluctuation of recyclables and recovered materials in Thailand during the last two years was within the range of ±20% as compared with the rate that has been used in the study. Taking into account similar price fluctuation in the future, the estimated net LCC is -11,300 ±3,400 baht/tonne of mixed recyclables.

caption.p: Net LCC of individual treatment technologies and intended integrated system in Nonthaburi Municipality.

sec.p: The estimated net LCC of AD amounts to 410 baht/tonne (Figure 3). It means that, notwithstanding all the possible revenue earnings by the sale of electricity (3.5 baht/kWh) and compost from sludge (2 baht/kg), the AD process is still not feasible as a single treatment method. Thus, additional revenue generation from the tipping fee and the earning of Certified Emissions Reduction (CER) credits under the Clean Development Mechanism, etc. would be needed to make the project commercially attractive.

As far as the incineration technology is concerned, the estimated net LCC is 2,290 baht per tonne of combustibles, which indicates that the potential revenue generation by selling the produced electricity may not be sufficient to meet the costs. Thus, adequate ways of generating revenue are needed to make this kind of project commercially attractive. There is little possibility of earning revenues from residual waste landfilling—the estimated net LCC amounts to 1,078 baht per tonne of waste.

The estimated net LCC of the intended integrated system amounts to –1,832 baht/tonne (Figure 3). This result proved that as a reward for initiating an integrated system, ‘net earnings’ of 1,832 baht per each tonne of MSW is possible. Despite the economical losses from AD, incineration and landfilling technologies, remarkable financial benefits in the form of ‘net earnings’ through the integrated system from 24% of waste recycling are possible. However, to earn adequate revenues from the intended integrated system, measures have to be taken to reduce the cost of incineration and AD while enhancing ways of additional revenue generation.

sec.title: Quantification of‘damage to human health’
sec.p: Based on the life cycle inventory analysis results of recycling, incineration, AD and landfilling, the life cycle emissions based health damages were quantified as mortality, severe morbidity and morbidity that would occur through various disease occurrence pathways. Then, all the effects were added to estimate the total health damage, expressed in terms of DALYs. As shown in Figure 4, the contribution from recycling to avoiding damage to human health is substantial. AD also contributes to preventing the occurrence of damage to human health by avoiding an impact on global warming and, therefore, human health, which would otherwise have occurred from the production process of a similar amount of conventional electricity.

caption.p: Damage to human health from individual treatment technologies and intended integrated system.

sec.p: Waste incineration is associated with energy recovery. Therefore, it is possible to avoid fossil CO2 and other toxic gas emissions from conventional electricity production (Brinck et al., 2011). However, incineration plants in Thailand, owing to low efficiency, emit more fossil-based CO2 emission than the potential savings. In fact, 90% of health damage from incineration arise from global warming as a result of the large fossil-based CO2 emissions released during the combustion of plastic, textile and rubber/leather waste. The remaining 10% of health damages occur from direct and indirect exposure to human toxic compounds, including NOx, SOx, and particulate matter. Landfilling of residual waste also contributes to minor health effects. Landfilling contributes to low emissions of toxic gases, for example CH4 and NH3 while the transportation and sorting of the waste contributes to emissions of toxic gases, such as CO2 and NOx, which may be hazards to health.

By aggregating the potential occurrence of all health hazards from different technologies, the severity of health damages from the intended integrated system were quantified. As shown in Figure 4, the overall health impact is shown as a negative value, indicating that the proposed integrated system has the capacity to avoid damage to health. However, it should be noted that the contribution from 24% of waste recycling on mitigating the occurrence of damage to health is substantial. This assessment has provided important information with respect to occurrence/avoidance of health hazards owing to the various emissions from individual technologies, as well as from the intended integrated system. This would be a very good indication to make a decision on sustainability.

sec.title: Quantification of ‘income-based community well-being’
sec.p: At present, the community in Nonthaburi Municipality earns a significant amount of money by selling point source separated recyclables. In fact, indirect income generation potential for the community by selling recyclables is 17,440 baht/tonne. In addition, the recycling process chain has created a significant number of employment opportunities in various hierarchical positions (e.g. from waste collectors to the managing directors) which amounts to 7.5 labour days per tonne of generated recyclables. The wages-based income-generation potential is 2,860 baht per tonne of recyclables. Thus, the total income generation potential from direct (selling recyclables) and indirect (wages based) sources of the recycling process is 20,300 baht/tonne of recyclables. As far as AD, incineration and landfilling are concerned, the major way of improving the well-being would be by providing an adequate number of skilled employment opportunities (Figure 5). Wages-based income generation potential from such technologies is also summarized in Figure 5.

caption.p: Income generation and creation of employment opportunities from individual treatment technologies and intended integrated system.

sec.p: By aggregating the social benefits of different technologies, income-based community well-being was determined for the indented integrated system. The estimated income to the community from both indirect income and wages-based income amounts to 5,360 baht/tonne of generated MSW management in Nonthaburi. To provide a meaningful explanation the ‘per capita living expenses’ of a middle class person (5000 baht per month) was considered in Thailand. Consequently, the generated income per tonne of waste would be sufficient to at least cover the monthly expenses of one person thereby contributing to enhancing quality of life.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The proposed indicators were found to be useful for the prior evaluation of three-dimensional sustainability as they are closer to the actual damages and are thus easier to comprehend at the decision-making stage with respect to planning and implementation of sustainable MSW management projects. In addition, the results of the endpoint composite indicators represent the aggregated impacts of the most relevant damages/effects of MSW management systems, which cannot be fully captured by any individual midpoint indicators. As far as the applicability of this protocol is concerned, policy-makers or local authorities can develop a simple spreadsheet model by following the step-by-step procedure explained in this article to quantify the ultimate damages/effects from waste management systems. Once the damages/effects from different waste management options are quantified, the results can be compared and the most sustainable waste management system can be selected for a particular municipality.

For instance, the analysis results of the case study in Nonthaburi revealed that efficiency of the materials and energy recovery potential from different technologies are the key driving forces for the level of sustainability. Recycling has been recognized as the most sustainable technology owing to the potential of a high materials recovery rate. Therefore, the overall sustainability of the designed integrated waste management system in Nonthaburi is highly sensitive to the recycling rate. According to the policy targets, if Nonthaburi Municipality initiates an integrated system with a 30% recycling rate (instead of the current rate of 24%) the MSW management system would have the potential of further improving all the sustainability aspects by more than 20%.

Apart from that, upgrading of the efficiency of electricity production from incineration and AD methods would significantly improve the overall sustainability of the integrated system. Application of advanced technologies for complete combustion, utilization of combined heat and power, and enhancement of the maintenance activities of the incineration plant, etc. would improve the energy recovery and, consequently, overall sustainability of incineration (Brinck et al., 2011; Fruergaard and Astrup, 2009). Furthermore, a high biogas yield and electric efficiency can be expected from AD by maintaining an appropriate temperature, retention time, volumetric loading and the degree of pre-treatment of feedstock.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: An integrated system was considered for Nonthaburi Municipality as a solution towards improved sustainability to overcome the existing waste management crisis. To assess the three- dimensional sustainability, a comprehensive methodology was presented and the most relevant composite indicators were proposed considering the ultimate damages/effects of MSW management via the LCA perspective. The proposed indicators were found to be useful for prior evaluation of three-dimensional sustainability of MSW management and decision-making with respect to planning and implementation of sustainable MSW management projects.

The proposed indicators were used to test the effectiveness of the integrated system via quantitative assessment of the sustainability attributes. Out of all the technologies assessed, recycling was found to be the most promising technology with regard to its potential for driving the entire system towards improved sustainability. AD and incineration were found to contribute to environmental and social sustainability. However, those technologies were found to be not economically sustainable owing to their high investment and operational costs. The enhancement of efficiencies of those technologies is therefore required to enable improving overall sustainability. Based on the proposed assessment framework detailed in this article, the research findings obtained from the case study evaluated in this work for Thailand could considerably help in strengthening law enforcement and support policy initiatives for moving towards more sustainable MSW management plans via an integrated approach.
